title: 110_s3363
content: The Act may be cited as the "Section 515 Rural Housing Property Transfer Improvement Act of 2008". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress acknowledges the importance of rural housing for poor families in the United States, particularly through the financing of rural multifamily housing under section 515 of the Housing Act of 1949. Many of these projects, which were built over 25 years ago, require new financing to continue providing affordable housing. Owners are seeking to transfer these properties, often combining federal resources with private and commercial funding. The Secretary of Agriculture should protect section 515 projects by facilitating ownership transfers in a timely manner to preserve affordable housing for eligible families. SEC. 3. TRANSFERS OF SECTION 515 RURAL MULTIFAMILY HOUSING PROJECTS. Section 515(h) of the Housing Act of 1949 is amended to expedite the approval of applications to transfer ownership of projects for preservation and rehabilitation. This includes making administrative and procedural changes, increasing staff and resources, and improving outreach to project sponsors. The Secretary of Agriculture aims to streamline approval processes for transferring project ownership, consulting with relevant agencies to simplify coordination of rules and requirements for housing projects receiving assistance. The Secretary of Agriculture facilitates transfers of project ownership for preservation and rehabilitation, with final regulatory authority held by the Office of Rental Housing Preservation. The Office of Rental Housing Preservation, under the Secretary of Agriculture, collaborates with State Rural Development offices for transfer recommendations. Deadlines are set for processing ownership transfer applications, with consequences for missed deadlines. The Office of Rental Housing Preservation, under the Secretary of Agriculture, collaborates with State Rural Development offices for transfer recommendations. Deadlines are set for processing ownership transfer applications, with consequences for missed deadlines. The application for transfer must be processed and approved or denied by the Office of Rental Housing Preservation within a specified timeframe. The State Rural Development office sets deadlines for processing ownership transfer applications based on the number of projects involved. The Office of Rental Housing Preservation must approve or deny transfer applications within specific timeframes. Ownership transfer applications must be processed and approved or denied within specific timeframes based on the number of projects involved: 30 days for a single project, 60 days for multiple projects (up to 10), and 120 days for 11 or more projects. Only decisions on complete applications can be appealed to the National Appeals Board. Ownership transfer applications must be appealable to the National Appeals Division of the Department of Agriculture. SEC. 4. REPORT. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report by July 1, 2008, to the Senate and House committees detailing coordination with other federal agencies and improvements made as a result. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report by July 1, 2008, detailing improvements in expediting ownership transfers of projects with loans under section 515 of the Housing Act of 1949 and recommending legislative changes for prompt processing of applications.
